content.body: AryehGregor: is there a way to contact the Wikimedia Language Committee by e-mail?
ah, found it
AryehGregor: see http://www.alvestrand.no/pipermail/ietf-languages/2006-November/005199.html
Amorphous: from Doug Ewell, who's closely involved with the language-tag registry
in reply to Gerard Meijssen asking about what WMF should do about language tags
Doug replied that they should do the "x-" thing
so I guess the change you made to the home page aligns with that
I've landed the </script> tokenization change on mozilla-central.
should be in the next batch of nightlies
in fact, trunk should now be in sync with the spec except for <spacer>
<span sandbox="random_token"><plaintext>...user-generated content...</span sandbox="same_token">
That should solve Michal Zalewski's point 2.2, assuming the sandbox parser is properly sandboxing
doesn't really want to imagine how such a parser would be implemented
How is the attribute "required" supposed to work in html5 when applied to only one radio input if the others don't have it?
you only need to set it on one of the radio buttons
basically
And it doesn't matter which. Any suggestion as per what would constitute "elegant coding"?
AKA What Would Xhtml2 Do?
xhtml2 would use xforms, so i don't know if that's what i'd do :-)
i'd recommend putting required on all the radio buttons if they're supposed to be required
I see.
but really a required radio button set is a bit dubious -- you're only need it if you hadn't checked a radio button to start with
and generally speaking it's better to check a radio button first
instead of having none et
set, even
By the way, how does that compare to <select>? Does required fail in a <select> dropdown? (the first element is always selected, at least in most UA)
Ah, there's no such thing as required for select.
Funny.
yeah there's no way to not have something selected
gotta go, reffing an fll regional
back later
Thanks Ian.
Have fun.
http://www.codinghorror.com/blog/

"We're overloading the class attribute with two meanings. Is "adr" the name of a class that contains styling information, or the name of a data field? (...) the semantics of the class attribute have been permanently altered."
Class is for CSS, it seems
Yeah I'm puzzled too, "css class" means nothing.

This attribute assigns a class name or set of class names to an element. Any number of elements may be assigned the same class name or names. Multiple class names must be separated by white space characters.
Nothing about css in http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/struct/global.html#h-7.5.2
